title: Module 1: What is CSE?
body:
Module 1:

What is CSE?

title: Key terms in CSE
instruction: Click on the buttons to explore some of the key terms, definitions and features associated with CSE:

_items.title: Child sexual exploitation (CSE)
_items.body:
Department for Education defines child sexual exploitation (CSE) as:

Child sexual exploitation is a form of child sexual abuse. It occurs where an individual or group takes advantage of an imbalance of power to coerce, manipulate or deceive a child or young person under the age of 18 into sexual activity (a) in exchange for something the victim needs or wants, and/or (b) for the financial advantage or increased status of the perpetrator or facilitator. The victim may have been sexually exploited even if the sexual activity appears consensual. Child sexual exploitation does not always involve physical contact; it can also occur through the use of technology.

One of the key factors found in most cases of child sexual exploitation is the presence of some form of exchange (sexual activity in return for something); for the victim and/or perpetrator or facilitator. Where it is the victim who is offered, promised or given something they need or want, the exchange can include both tangible (such as money, drugs, shelter, food or alcohol) and intangible rewards (such as status, protection or perceived receipt of love or affection).

It is important to note that the abuse can be a one-off occurrence or a series of incidents over time and range from opportunistic to complex organised abuse including online.

REF: Department for Education - Child sexual exploitation

_items.title: Child sexual abuse (CSA)
_items.body:
Government guidance defines child sexual abuse (CSA) as:

‘Involving, forcing or enticing a child or young person to take part in sexual activities, not necessarily involving a high level of violence, whether or not the child is aware what is happening.’

REF: HM Government - Working together to safeguard children

_items.title: Receiving something
_items.body:
The person affected by CSE receives 'something' in return for performing and/or having others perform sexual activities on them. The ‘something’ may be money, gifts, accommodation, affection or status.

These are deliberate tactics to befriend them, lure them into sexual activity and trap them into feeling that they are somehow indebted to the abuser. There is evidence of forced or coerced sex by young people against young people.

_items.title: Power
_items.body:
CSE always involves one person or a group of people having power over another person by virtue of their age, gender, intellect, physical strength, social status and/or economic resources.

The power can be exerted manipulatively (e.g. sexual activity in exchange for social status or accommodation) or, increasingly it is being exerted through violence, with threats to the young person or their family. Forced sex by peers is also increasing.

_items.title: Vulnerability
_items.body:
Vulnerability means being susceptible to the possibility of being harmed. Something about the person or circumstances leaves them open to abuse and abusers often identify these vulnerable children and young people and work to desensitise and violate the child’s boundaries.

REMEMBER: Any young person can be vulnerable to CSE.

_items.title: Characteristics of the relationship
_items.body:
Some abusers use tactics to charm and be likeable. They radiate sincerity and truthfulness.

In reality, the relationship involves an imbalance of power that limits the options of the person being exploited, meaning they are unable to make an informed choice to consent to sexual activity.

_items.title: Contextual safeguarding
_items.body:
This focuses on the context in which the abuse occurs, for example in the community, at school, online or on transport.

Principle Research Fellow at the University of Bedfordshire, Dr Carlene Firmin, summarises contextual safeguarding as recognising ‘that the different relationships that young people form in their neighbourhoods, schools and online can feature violence and abuse’.

REF: Dr Carlene Firmin - Contextual Safeguarding

_items.title: Consent
_items.body:
Consent is a complex issue which both professionals and young people have failed to always properly understand. It is important to think about the context under which a child has sex and think about if the child has the freedom, capacity or ability to choose the sexual activity that they engage in.

  • The age of consent to sex is 16 years old
  • Any sexual activity involving under 16-year-olds is unlawful though the court takes into account the circumstances of peer-to-peer sex
  • Fraser guidelines are used to decide if a young person can consent to contraceptive or sexual health advice and treatment under the age of 16
  • Sexual activity with under 13s is unlawful and they do not have legal capacity to consent
  • What comprises ‘sexual activity’ is very broad and ranges from penetration and inciting sexual activity to watching sexual acts

'Sexual Offences Act' 2003

title: The current picture
body: The prevalence of child sexual abuse is challenging to measure. The true number of those experiencing CSE is unknown.
instruction: Click on the hotspots to explore the current picture around CSE:

_graphic.alt: 7 individual graphics representing different areas of the current picture around CSE.

mobileBody: The prevalence of child sexual abuse is challenging to measure. The true number of those experiencing CSE is unknown.
mobileInstruction: Work your way through the slider and click on the buttons to explore the current picture around CSE:

_items.title: Reporting
_items.body:
Research suggests that boys and young men are less likely to report experiences of CSE.

REF: Boys and Young Men at Risk of Sexual Exploitation

_graphic.alt: Graphic of a speaker phone.

_items.title: Sexual abuse
_items.body:
In cases of sexual abuse:

  • 37% of cases are most likely to have been carried out by a friend or acquaintance
  • 30% of cases are most likely to have been carried out by a stranger

REF: Crime Survey for England and Wales (CSEW) 2020

_graphic.alt: Graphic of lightening bolts with the wording '30% of cases by a stranger'.

_items.title: Embarrassment
_items.body:
Most of the victims cited ‘embarrassment’ as the main reason why they did not tell anyone about their sexual abuse at the time.

REF: Crime Survey for England and Wales (CSEW) 2020

_graphic.alt: Graphic of an embarrassed face.

_items.title: Ethnicity
_items.body:
The Children’s Society have noted that CSE amongst Black and Minority Ethnic Groups (BME) groups continues to go under reported and unidentified.

REF: The Children’s Society: Supporting Black and Minority Ethnic Children and Young People Experiencing Child Sexual Exploitation 2018

_graphic.alt: Graphic of 3 people representing different ethnicities.

_items.title: Online abuse
_items.body:
Online abuse is increasingly being used as a means of grooming and abuse.

In 2018/19 the NSPCC had 1,507 calls to their helpline where online abuse was the main concern; a 19% increase on the previous year.

REF: NSPCC - How safe are our children?

_graphic.alt: Graphic of a computer with the wording '1507 calls to NSPCC helpline'.

_items.title: Social media
_items.body:
In a 3-month period, Facebook reported removing 8.7 million pieces of content globally for breaching policies on child nudity and sexual exploitation.

REF: Online Harms White Paper 2020

_graphic.alt: Graphic of a thumb pointing up and a thumb pointing down with the wording '8.7 million facebook posts removed (3 month period)'.

_items.title: Law enforcement
_items.body:
UK law enforcement organisations arrest around 450 people and safeguard over 600 children each month through their efforts to combat online CSE.

REF: Home Office factsheet on online sexual exploitation and abuse (2019)

_graphic.alt: Graphic of a legal document with the wording '450 arrests & 600 safeguarded children'.

title: Module 2: Spotting the signs
body:
Module 2:

Spotting the signs

title: Spotting the signs
body:
It’s important that you look out for the physical, psychological or behavioural signs of CSE. These will prompt you to ask further questions.

REMEMBER: If you have any suspicions that a child or young person is being mistreated in any way, talk to someone who has responsibility for safeguarding and make a note of your concerns.
instruction: Click on the buttons to explore examples of the different signs of CSE:

_items.title: Physical signs
_items.body:
• Late presentation of untreated injuries or illnesses
  • Self-harm
  • Unexplained injuries
  • Rapid change in appearance
  • ‘Revolving door’ with A&E or Police
  • Repeated STIs and frequent testing
  • Repeated urinary tract infections
  • Repeat request of emergency contraception
  • Pelvic-inflammatory disease
  • Repeat pregnancy
  • Repeat alcohol abuse
  • Drugs and solvent abuse
  • Physical injuries

_items.title: Psychological signs
_items.body:
• Psychological health problems
  • Suicidal ideation
  • Multiple personality disorders
  • Dissociation
  • Depression
  • Sleep disorders
  • Eating disorders
  • Post-traumatic stress disorder
  • Alcohol drug or substance abuse
  • Self-harming
  • Low self-esteem

_items.title: Behavioural signs
_items.body:
• Often running away/missing from home
  • Inappropriate sexual behaviour
  • Repeated absence from school
  • Dropping out of school and/or failing exams
  • Unemployment
  • Criminal behaviour
  • Bullying as a victim or perpetrator
  • Lethargy
  • Suicide and suicide attempts
  • Self-blame (big problem even with successes)
  • Disruptive or challenging behaviour
  • Accepting gifts from unknown sources
  • Chaotic lifestyle
  • Homelessness
  • Becoming pregnant at a young age
  • Becoming isolated from family and friends
  • Struggle with trust and fear of forming new relationships
  • Secretive
  • Receiving lots of phone calls, taking phone calls always away from family or friends, deleting phone history including calls and messages

_graphic.alt: Graphic of three question marks.

title: Indicators
body: As children and young people rarely self-report child sexual exploitation, there are many potential indicators of risk that it is important to be aware of.
instruction: Work your way through the slider to see some of the indicators for CSE:
mobileInstruction: Work your way through the slider to see some of the indicators for CSE:

_graphic.alt: Image of a teddy bear upright on a bed facing away.
Image of a boy wearing a cap walking away.
Image of a boy sat with numerous empty beer bottles.
Image of a hooded person walking down a street.
Image of a girl from above grabbing onto the hair on the top of her head.

_items.title: Reduced contact with family and friends

_graphic.alt: Image of a girl sat alone in a bedroom.

_items.strapline: Reduced contact with family and friends

_graphic.alt: Image of a girl laid on a bed in lingerie.

title: Module 3: Safeguarding young people
body:
Module 3:

Safeguarding
young people

title: Clear explanations
body: As a professional working with children and young people it is important that you take time to clearly explain processes and rights in a way that they understand.
instruction: Click on the tabs for more information:

_items.title: Explaining confidentiality
_items.body:
It is important to explain the limits of confidentiality to a young person at the beginning of any interaction.

Explain that it means you won’t talk about a consultation to anyone without their permission unless they or someone else is in serious danger. If there are any worries or questions about confidentiality, encourage them to ask you.

Also make sure your approach to confidentiality adheres to that of your organisation.

_items.title: Explaining risks and the law
_items.body:
Children and young people may not understand the situation they are in is abusive or may have trouble accepting that something bad has happened or is happening to them.

As a professional working with children and young people you can respect their rights and wishes by explaining the law and inviting them to participate with you in the actions you need to undertake to safeguard them from harmful.

Underage sexual activity should always be seen as a likely indicator of CSE or CSA (child sexual abuse). The Sexual Offences Act 2003 introduced a range of offences, including grooming and statutory rape of children under 13, which can be brought against perpetrators in CSE cases. Therefore, sexual activity with a child under 13 should always result in a child protection referral.

NSPCC: Gillick competency and Fraser guidelines

_graphic.alt: Image of two women sat down at a table talking.

title: Test your knowledge
body: Test your knowledge

title: Resource bank
instruction: Click on the tabs for more information:

_items.title: Association for Young People's Health (AYPH)
_items.body:
AYPH is the independent voice for young people’s health. They believe that young people have a right to good health and high quality accessible healthcare.

Association for Young People's Health (AYPH)

Be Healthy project

From 2011-2015, together with the University of Bedfordshire, AYPH ran the Be Healthy project on the health needs of young people affected by sexual exploitation.

The Be Healthy project

_items.title: Barnardo's
_items.body:
Barnardo's was founded in 1866 and supports sexually exploited children running specialist services in various locations across the UK.

Barnardo's

It’s not on the radar

A 2015 report into the hidden diversity of children and young people at risk of sexual exploitation in England.

It’s not on the radar

_items.title: Basis Yorkshire
_items.body:
Basis Yorkshire provides safety, information and support to sexworkers living and/or working in Leeds (female including trans, indoor or on the street) as well as young people (boys, girls, young women and young men) experiencing or at risk of sexual exploitation.

Basis Yorkshire

_items.title: Brook
_items.body:
Brook is a UK charity that helps young people up to the age of 25 with their sexual health, relationships and wellbeing. Established in 1964, Brook is the only national charity to deliver a blend of clinical, educational and wellbeing services that address young people’s immediate needs and build understanding of the importance of positive and healthy relationships.

Brook

Sexual Behaviours Traffic Light Tool

Brook’s nationally recognised Sexual Behaviours Traffic Light Tool training (revised and updated in 2020) provides a highly visible, multi-agency response that helps professionals to identify, understand and respond appropriately to sexual behaviours in young people.

Sexual Behaviours Traffic Light Tool

Spotting the Signs - A National Proforma (CSE)

The British Association for Sexual Health and HIV (BASHH) and Brook developed a child sexual exploitation (CSE) proforma, Spotting the Signs (review due 2020), to help health professionals across the UK identify young people attending sexual health services who may be at risk of or experiencing sexual exploitation.

Spotting the Signs - A National Proforma (CSE)

_items.title: Centre of expertise on child sexual abuse
_items.body:
The Centre of expertise on child sexual abuse is a multi-disciplinary team, funded by the Home Office and hosted by Barnardo’s and works closely with key partners from academic institutions, local authorities, health, education, police and the voluntary sector.

Centre of expertise on child sexual abuse

Scoping report (2018)

A key aim of the Centre is to increase understanding and awareness of the scale and nature of child sexual abuse (CSA). This paper forms the background to reaching current best estimates for both CSA and child sexual exploitation (CSE), as part of a strand of work which seeks to improve measurement and identify gaps in knowledge.

Measuring the scale and changing nature of child sexual abuse and child sexual exploitation: Scoping report (2018)

_items.title: Child Exploitation and Online Protection Command (CEOP)
_items.body:
CEOP is a command of the UK's National Crime Agency (NCA), and is tasked to work both nationally and internationally to bring online child sex offenders, including those involved in the production, distribution and viewing of child abuse material, to the UK courts.

Child Exploitation and Online Protection Command (CEOP)

What is online child sexual abuse and exploitation?

A useful summary of key terms including CSE, CSA, online grooming and Live Streaming.

What is online child sexual abuse and exploitation?

_items.title: The Children's Commissioner
_items.body:
The Children’s Commissioner for England is Anne Longfield OBE. She speaks up for children and young people so that policymakers and the people who have an impact on their lives take their views and interests into account when making decisions about them.

Independent of Government and Parliament, the Children’s Commissioner has unique powers to help bring about long-term change and improvements for all children, particularly the most vulnerable.

The Children's Commissioner

If only someone had listened

The Office of the Children's Commissioner's Inquiry into Child Sexual Exploitation in Gangs and Groups, 2013.

If only someone had listened

Keeping Kids Safe report

This report investigates what it means to be a child gang member in England. It estimates how many children in England are in gangs, and looks at the risks factors which make it more likely for a child to end up being groomed for gang membership.

Finally, it questions whether those responsible for safeguarding children are responding adequately to the rise in gang violence and how children can better be kept safe.

Keeping Kids Safe: Improving safeguarding responses to gang violence and criminal exploitation (2019)

_items.title: The Children's Society
_items.body:
The Children's Society is a charity working to support vulnerable children in England and Wales.

The Children's Society

Advocacy Services for Children and Young People

This guide is to help those responsible for children’s services to plan and design independent, professional advocacy services so that they have the greatest positive impact on the lives of children and young people.

Advocacy Services for Children and Young People

Boys and Young Men at Risk of Sexual Exploitation - A toolkit for professionals (2018)

Based on the understanding and the evidence picture in 2018 of child sexual exploitation in relation to boys and young men, this toolkit was produced by The Children’s Society as part of the National CSAE Prevention Programme for England and Wales, in partnership with Victim Support and the National Police Chiefs’ Council (NPCC).

Boys and Young Men at Risk of Sexual Exploitation: A toolkit for professionals (2018)

_items.title: The Coffey Inquiry
_items.body:
The Coffey Inquiry (named after Ann Coffey MP) looked into on at what changes have been made in safeguarding children from sexual exploitation by Greater Manchester Police and partner agencies since the Rochdale sexual grooming case, and at what more needs to be done in the future.

The Coffey Inquiry

_items.title: Department for Education
_items.body:
The Department for Education is responsible for children’s services and education, including early years, schools, higher and further education policy, apprenticeships and wider skills in England.

Department for Education

Definition and Guide for practitioners, local leaders, and decision makers working to protect children from child sexual exploitation (2017)

This advice was produced to help practitioners, local leaders and decision makers who work with children and families to identify child sexual exploitation and take appropriate action in response. This includes the management, disruption and prosecution of perpetrators.

Definition and Guide for practitioners, local leaders, and decision makers working to protect children from child sexual exploitation (2017)

Child sexual exploitation: support in children’s residential homes research report (2016)

This study was commissioned by the Department for Education to start filling the evidence gap around the tailored support provided to children affected by CSE who are placed in residential care.

Child sexual exploitation: support in children’s residential homes research report (2016)

_items.title: Department of Health
_items.body:
The Department of Health and Social Care supports ministers in leading the nation’s health and social care to help people live more independent, healthier lives for longer.

Department of Health

Health working group report on Child Sexual Exploitation

An independent group chaired by the Department of Health focusing on improving the outcomes for children by promoting effective engagement of health services and staff.

Health working group report on Child Sexual Exploitation

Information: To share or not to Share (2013)

This report is the Government response to the Caldicott Review which was commissioned by the Chief Medical Officer of England owing to increasing concern about the ways in which patient information was being used in the NHS in England and Wales and the need to ensure that confidentiality is not undermined.

Information: To share or not to Share (2013)

_items.title: HM Government
_items.body:
The Government of the United Kingdom, formally and commonly referred to as Her Majesty's Government, is the central government of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland.

HM Government

Working Together to Safeguard Children

A guide to inter-agency working to safeguard and promote the welfare of children (July 2018).

Working Together to Safeguard Children

Information sharing

Advice for practitioners providing safeguarding services to children, young people, parents and carers (July 2018).

Information sharing

Multi-Agency Working and Information Sharing Project: Early Findings (July 2013)

Early findings from a Home Office funded project to improve national and local understanding of the different local multi-agency models in place to support information sharing around safeguarding responses for children and vulnerable people.

Multi-Agency Working and Information Sharing Project: Early Findings (July 2013)

Children and Social Work Act (2017)

An Act to make provision about looked after children; to make other provision in relation to the welfare of children; and to make provision about the regulation of social workers.

Children and Social Work Act (2017)

The multi-agency response to child sexual abuse in the family environment

The findings in this report consider the extent to which children’s social care, health professionals, youth offending services, the police and probation officers effectively work together to safeguard children who are subject to, or at risk of, sexual abuse in the family environment.

The multi-agency response to child sexual abuse in the family environment

_items.title: The Independent Inquiry Child Sexual Abuse
_items.body:
The Independent Inquiry into Child Sexual Abuse, chaired by Professor Alexis Jay OBE was set up because of serious concerns that some organisation had failed and were continuing to fail to protect children from sexual abuse.

The Independent Inquiry Child Sexual Abuse

The Truth Project

The Truth Project offers the opportunity for Victims and Survivors to share their experience and be respectfully heard and acknowledged. By doing so, they will help IICSA to better understand the long term impact of abuse. Their contribution will help IICSA make recommendations about support needs, as well as challenging our assumptions of child sexual abuse.

The Truth Project

_items.title: Internet Watch Foundation
_items.body:
The Internet Watch Foundation (IWF) is a registered charity that aims to minimise the availability of online sexual abuse content, specifically child sexual abuse images and videos hosted anywhere in the world and non-photographic child sexual abuse images hosted in the UK.

Internet Watch Foundation

_items.title: Jay Report: Independent CSE inquiry in Rotherham
_items.body:
This Independent Inquiry was commissioned by Rotherham Metropolitan Borough Council in October 2013, covering the periods of 1997- 2009 and 2009 - 2013.

Jay Report: Independent CSE inquiry in Rotherham

_items.title: Lucy Faithfull Foundation
_items.body:
The Lucy Faithfull Foundation is the only UK-wide charity dedicated solely to tackling child sexual abuse.

Lucy Faithfull Foundation

_items.title: Marie Collins Foundation
_items.body:
The Marie Collins Foundation is the UK charity enabling children who suffer sexual abuse and exploitation via internet and mobile technologies to recover and live safe, fulfilling lives.

Marie Collins Foundation

_items.title: NAPAC
_items.body:
NAPAC (the National Association for People Abused in Childhood) offers support to adult survivors of all types of childhood abuse, including physical, sexual, emotional abuse or neglect.

NAPAC

_items.title: National Institute of Clinical Excellence (NICE)
_items.body:
The National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) provides national guidance and advice to improve health and social care.

National Institute of Clinical Excellence (NICE)

When to suspect child maltreatment overview

This guideline covers the signs of possible child maltreatment in children and young people aged under 18 years. It aims to raise awareness and help health professionals who are not child protection specialists to identify the features of physical, sexual and emotional abuse, neglect and fabricated or induced illness.

When to suspect child maltreatment overview

_items.title: NSPCC
_items.body:
The National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children (NSPCC) is a charity campaigning and working in child protection in the United Kingdom and the Channel Islands.

NSPCC

What is child sexual exploitation?

If you're worried about sexual exploitation, the NSPCC have information and advice to protect and help children and young people.

What is child sexual exploitation?

Serious Case Review on Behalf of an Unnamed Local Children Safeguarding Board (2019)

This Serious Case Review is in respect of Katie who was significantly harmed by sexual exploitation from the age of 14 years, starting when she was living at home and continuing when she was in the care of the local authority.

Serious Case Review on Behalf of an Unnamed Local Children Safeguarding Board (2019)

_items.title: NWG Network
_items.body:
The NWG Explotation Response Unit (formerly the National Working Group for Sexually Exploited Children and Young People) is a charity providing specialist support, training and resources for professionals from all sectors tackling child exploitation.

NWG Network

What’s going on to Safeguard Children and Young People from Sexual Exploitation? (2011)

The NWG and the University of Bedfordshire conducted research into Local Safeguarding Children Boards (LSCBs) to understand how they had responded to the 2009 government guidance on safeguarding children and young people from sexual exploitation.

What’s going on to Safeguard Children and Young People from Sexual Exploitation? (University of Bedfordshire, 2011)

_items.title: PACE
_items.body:
Pace works alongside parents and carers of children who are – or are at risk of being – exploited by perpetrators external to the family. They offer guidance and training to professionals on how child exploitation affects the whole family.

PACE

Child sexual exploitation grooming models

Information on how perpetrators ‘groom’ a child for sexual exploitation in a process designed to break down the child’s defences and existing relationships with family and friends to establish control.

Child sexual exploitation grooming models

_items.title: Public Health England
_items.body:
PHE exists to protect and improve the nation’s health and wellbeing, and reduce health inequalities and is an executive agency, sponsored by the Department of Health and Social Care.

Public Health England

Child sexual exploitation: prevention and intervention

This report summarises the emerging evidence from the UK on the issue of child sexual exploitation. It provides practice examples to support local public health leaders to establish a public health framework for prevention and intervention.

Child sexual exploitation: prevention and intervention

_items.title: Victim Support
_items.body:
Victim Support is an independent charity dedicated to supporting people affected by crime and traumatic incidents in England and Wales.

Victim Support

title: Quote
body:
“Any young person, from any social ethnic background, boys and young men as well as girls and young women, can be exploited.”

REF: Barnardo's, 'It's not on the radar' (2015)

title: Quote
body:
“I wouldn’t want anybody else to go through what I went through.”

REF: Independent Inquiry Child Sexual Abuse, The Truth Project

title: Terminology and language
body:
The terminology and language used when working with CSE is changing.

As highlighted in recent serious case reviews (NSPCC 2019), the language used when working with young people is really important to get right. We must always see CSE through a child-centred lens.

Recent guidance from The Children’s Society, Victim Support and the NSPCC stresses that we must:

  • Not use language that implies that a child or young person is complicit
  • Remember they have or are being abused, they have not had a choice in it
  • Recognise the serious harm that has been experienced
  • Remember that coercion has been used and emphasise the lack of control over the situation

NSPCC - Serious Case Review on Behalf of an Unnamed Local Children Safeguarding Board (2019)
instruction: Click on the button for more information:

_items.title: The impact of inappropriate language
_items.body:
By using language that insinuates that a child or young person has had a choice or has chosen a ‘lifestyle’, we are in effect using victim-blaming language.

This could have the effect of:

  • Reinforcing messages from their perpetrator
  • Preventing them from disclosing for fear of being blamed or ashamed
  • Normalising or minimising their experience of abuse

As a result, the child or young person might not return to our services, and we might not be able to protect them from ongoing harm.

_graphic.alt: Image of a female teacher helping a female student.

title: Guidance around the use of appropriate language
displayTitle: Guidance around the use of appropriate language
body:
The Children Society’s guidance highlights the following examples of correcting language used in relation to CSE.

The Children Society - Appropriate Language in CSE Guidance
instruction: Click on the buttons to see suggested alternatives for these inappropriate terms:

_items.title: 'Putting themselves at risk’
_items.body:
This implies that the child is responsible for the risks presented by the perpetrator and that they are able to make free and informed choices.

Suggested alternatives

  • The child may have been groomed
  • The child is at an increased vulnerability of being abused and/or exploited
  • A perpetrator may exploit the child’s increased vulnerability
  • The child is not in a protective environment
  • The situation could reduce the child’s safety
  • The location is dangerous to children.  The location/situation could increase a perpetrator’s opportunity to abuse them 
  • It is unclear whether the child is under duress to go missing
  • There are concerns that the child may be being sexually abused
  • It is unclear why the child is getting into cars
  • There are concerns that there is a power imbalance forcing the child to act in this way

_items.title: ‘In a relationship with’
_items.body:
This implies that the child or young person is in a consensual relationship and does not reflect the abusive or exploitative context.

Suggested alternatives

  • The young person says that they are in a relationship with a person and there are concerns about that person’s age, the imbalance of power, exploitation and/or offending
  • The young person has been/is being groomed, exploited and controlled

_items.title: 'Involved in CSE’
_items.body:
This implies there is a level of choice regarding the child being abused. A five-year-old would never be referred to as being involved in sexual abuse for the same reasons.

Suggested alternatives

  • The child is vulnerable to being sexually exploited
  • The child is being sexually exploited

title: Quote
body:
“What people don't realise is that it scars you for life.”

REF: CEOP 2011, Thematic Assessment

title: Real stories
body: Experiences of CSE are as individual as the people themselves.
instruction: Click on the hotspots to explore a selection individual stories, that all represent examples of CSE:
mobileBody: Experiences of CSE are as individual as the people themselves.
mobileInstruction: Work your way through the slider and click on the buttons to explore a selection individual stories, that all represent examples of CSE:

_items.title: Case 1
_items.body:
Adrienne was 15. She remembers how ‘cool’ it felt to have an older person who took an interest in her. She adds that they ‘had a laugh and everything was free.

He would pick Adrienne up and buy her alcohol and drugs, and again, she relates how this attention made her feel ‘important’. She recounts that she often had to have sex with up to 10 men each night.

_graphic.alt: Image of a glass of alcohol.

_items.title: Case 2
_items.body: ‘Being gay at 15 wasn't an issue but I had some issues with depression and started to self-harm. A friend asked me to go to meet a guy he'd met on the internet. We sometimes went to his flat and watched TV and had a drink or two. Before I knew it I was being introduced to this guy's 'friends' who wanted sex.’

_graphic.alt: Image of a boy on a computer.

_items.title: Case 3
_items.body: ‘My Bangladeshi friend was 15 years old when she met a boy on social media - he was 23. They chatted for 6 months then they met. He pressurised her into having sex and said “Give me something so I can remember you.” He promised to marry her but then passed her on to his best friend. Now they share her.’

_graphic.alt: Image of a person on their phone.

_items.title: Case 4
_items.body: Chris aged 13, had extensive special educational needs, including ADHD. Police report that Chris was believed to be being targeted by gangs because he was easily influenced. Shortly after this Chris was arrested for a sexual assault. The police did not take this forward but did again refer him to children’s services. Chris repeatedly went missing, was not attending school. He was known to 12 agencies when he was shot and killed aged 14.

_graphic.alt: Image of a silhouette of a boy looking away.

_items.title: Case 5
_items.body:
Sean 15, describes himself as “autistic, gay and from the traveller community”. Due to harsh attitudes against homosexuality, he was isolated from the traveller community, and further isolated due to his autism. Sean had a very violent father, which had resulted in Sean’s mother leaving. He kept his sexual orientation a secret as he knew what the reaction from the community would be.

After a very violent episode with his dad, Sean went online to meet men. He met a man who promised to look after him and invited Sean to stay with him. Sean knew that if he left the community, he would be unable to return, but he ran away to stay with the man. Sean was raped by the man, so he ran away, and was homeless. Having autism made living on the streets even harder; Sean’s mental health was poor, and he contemplated suicide.

_graphic.alt: Image of a homeless boy hunched over sat on the floor.

_items.title: Case 6
_items.body: Anya recounts a difficult neighbourhood and was at first approach by older men when she was in her early teens. She was eventually groomed via the boyfriend model, meeting a slightly older boy she really liked. But the boyfriend’s father raped her, and her exploitation continued as Anya was trafficked throughout the region.

_graphic.alt: Image of a hooded girl looking away.

title: Summary
body:
CSE occurs in all communities across the UK and much of it remains hidden, undisclosed and unreported.

As professionals working with young people, it’s important that we have the knowledge, confidence and skills to talk to young people in the right way, when we suspect exploitation is occurring.

title: Quote
body:
“CSE affects every aspect of our lives; our relationships, physical health, emotional health and self-esteem. It is really hard to deal with all of this at the same time.”

REF: Association of Young People's Health Partnership (AYPH), Be Healthy Project

title: Which of the following do you think might make a child more susceptible to CSE?
body: Which of the following do you think might make a child more susceptible to CSE?
instruction: Select all that apply:

_items.text: A disrupted family life and domestic violence
Being a looked after child
Being a refugee or asylum seeker
A history of physical or sexual abuse
Learning disabilities
Physical disabilities
Poor psychological health
Problematic parenting

_feedback.title: Feedback:
_feedback.correct:
That's right

All of these vulnerabilities might make a child more susceptible to child sexual exploitation.

_incorrect.final:
That's incorrect

All of these vulnerabilities might make a child more susceptible to child sexual exploitation.

_partlyCorrect.final:
That is partially correct

All of these vulnerabilities might make a child more susceptible to child sexual exploitation.

title: The role of family
body:
Sometimes family members fail to notice signs of abuse or, when they do notice that something isn’t right or the child discloses, they do not have the information or support to respond effectively.

We should engage with family members as they can help to gather vital information and can act in ways which help us protect children and young people.

The following will help earlier, more effective protection:

  • Raising awareness of signs and signals of abuse
  • Offering easy access information/advice to children and young people
  • Gauging supportively with family members

Pace: The Relational Safeguarding Model

_graphic.alt: Image of a young girl on a swing.

title: Working with young people
body:
Children and young people are clear about how they would like professionals to act when addressing potential CSE.

What do they want?

  • A non-judgmental approach
  • Limits to confidentiality explained clearly
  • To be treated respectfully and be kept fully informed if any safeguarding procedures are implemented
  • Support regarding the how, what and when to disclose
  • An approach where they are not made to feel different or are labelled as a ‘victim’
  • Trust, respect and communication

_graphic.alt: Image of a girl sat down with her face resting on her hands.

title: Missed opportunities and a child centred approach
displayTitle: Missed opportunities and a child centred approach
body:
It has been well documented that in the past, opportunities for intervention have been missed by all professional groups. There has been a view that young people are more in control of what is happening to them and they are choosing this ‘lifestyle’, when in fact they are unable to extricate themselves.

When we have a young person in front of us, our style of engagement is really important. If the attitude, tone of voice and questioning by services feels confrontational or lacking empathy, children and young people can feel alienated and they may disengage.

When they feel that they are listened to, understood and that the professional cares about their situation, they can feel much more empowered.

Independent Inquiry Child Sexual Abuse: The Truth Project

_graphic.alt: Image of a boy hunched over with his head resting on his folded arms.

title: Reasons for non-disclosure: Children and young people
displayTitle: Reasons for non-disclosure: Children and young people
body:
A lack of awareness about CSE means that children and young people are not informed about their boundaries, their rights and where they could turn for help.

Children and young people:

  • Do not always have the knowledge to recognise that the abuse is wrong
  • May feel that they are betraying the perpetrator
  • Are often coping with several problems at the same time
  • May feel that something is not ‘right’ but lack the confidence to confide in others
  • May not disclose as they are afraid that perpetrators won’t be prosecuted

Age-appropriate information and opportunities for disclosure at different touch points can greatly increase opportunities for intervention.

title: Reasons for non-disclosure: Boys and young men
displayTitle: Reasons for non-disclosure: Boys and young men
body: Working with boys and young men affected by CSE can bring additional challenges.
instruction: Work your way through the slider to explore further:
mobileInstruction: Work your way through the slider to explore further:

_items.title: Not wanting to be labelled a ‘victim’
_items.body:
This can make boys and young men feel weak, vulnerable and unwilling to disclose.

As The Children’s Society state, these are ‘qualities that run counter to the stereotype of a masculine male who can protect himself’.

REF: The Children’s Society - ‘Boys Don’t Cry’ Improving Identification and Disclosure of sexual exploitation amongst boys and young men trafficked to the UK (2016)

_graphic.alt: Image of a boy sat on a bench with his head dropped between his hands..

_items.strapline: Not wanting to be labelled a ‘victim’

_items.title: Aggression, violence and offending
_items.body: It is more likely that boys and young men will express their anger and trauma this way, which can often obscure what is really happening.

_graphic.alt: Image of crossed arms and blooded knuckles.

_items.title: Ethnic or cultural backgrounds
_items.body:
This may make boys and young men even less likely to disclose due to:

  • the stigma of same sex or pre-marital contact
  • a lack of understanding about abuse
  • not wanting their families to find out

REF: Boys and Young Men at Risk of Sexual Exploitation - A toolkit for professionals (2018)

_graphic.alt: Image of a boy putting his hand to his head.

_items.title: CSE campaigns and services are often aimed at girls
_items.body:
It is vital that when we see boys and young men in our services, we ask ourselves would our response be the same if we were working with a girl? Services should be gender-informed, with leaflets, and posters in waiting areas that target boys and young men. This will give them the confidence in knowing it is ok to come forward, and they will be listened to.

Where possible, have workers specifically for boys and young men and ensure that BME and LGBTQ+ communities are similarly represented.

REF: Boys and Young Men at Risk of Sexual Exploitation

_graphic.alt: Image of a girl looking at herself in a mirror.

_items.strapline: CSE campaigns and services are often aimed at girls

title: Summary
body:
A child may present with physical and psychological health issues that may raise concerns.

It can be very difficult for children and young people to talk about the abuse their experience, especially if they think that they are not believed and or nothing happens to stop it.

It is important to use professional curiosity and investigate issues further in an age appropriate way to ensure that the child or young person comes to no further harm.

title: Quote
body:
“Obviously if it happened to a person they’d be too embarrassed to say this happened to me… Cos like a boy got assaulted by another boy like, obviously sexually, he would never report it cos he’d be like, obviously you’re always gonna be labelled as like a homosexual… you might feel sorry for him yeah, but you’d think like how didn’t you defend yourself, you’re supposed to be a man… So, it’s not worth it, they’d just keep it to themselves.”

REF: Barnardo's - ‘It’s not on the radar’ (2015)

title: Quote
body:
“If you suspect, it’s better to be wrong than to be sorry. If you have a query you should speak up. It could change someone’s life”.

REF: Independent Inquiry Child Sexual Abuse, The Truth Project

title: What young people want
body:
Young people are clear what they want from an effective safeguarding system.

REF: HM Government, 2013 - Working Together to Safeguard Children
instruction: Click on the hotspots to find out more:

_graphic.alt: Image of 7 shapes with 7 individual people in them.

mobileBody: Young people are clear what they want from an effective safeguarding system.
mobileInstruction: Work your way through the slider and click on the buttons to explore further:

_items.title: Vigilance and professional curiosity
_items.body: We want adults to notice when things are troubling us. Listen to what the we are saying and hear it from a safeguarding perspective.

_graphic.alt: Image in a square shape of a young boy in a black jacket sat down.

_items.title: Understanding and action
_items.body: Hear us and understand what is happening and then act upon it.

_graphic.alt: Image in a tear drop shape of a girl with tight curly hair and no facial expression.

_items.title: Choices
_items.body: Exploitation takes our choices away, so it’s important that we are given the element of choice back.

_graphic.alt: Image in a triangle shape of a boy with afro hair wearing a scarf around his neck.

_items.title: Stability
_items.body: Develop an ongoing, stable relationship of trust with those helping us, and if possible, maintain the same professional involvement to suit our needs.

_graphic.alt: Image in a triangle shape of a girl leaning against a wired fence.

_items.title: Respect, information and engagement
_items.body: Treat us with the expectation that we are competent, rather than not. Keep us involved and informed about procedures, decisions, concerns and plans.

_graphic.alt: Image in a circle shape of a girl leaning against a brick wall.

_items.title: Advocacy and explanation
_items.body:
Provide us with advocacy to assist us in putting forward our views.

Then keep us informed about the outcome of assessments, decisions and reasons, when our views have not met with a positive response.

REF: The Children’s Society - Advocacy Services for Children and Young People

_graphic.alt: Image in a square shape of a boy sat down in a hoodie.

_items.title: Support that is free from judgement
_items.body:
Provide us with support in our own right, as well as a member of the family.

Don’t judge us; especially in relation to criminality and sexual activities.
_items.strapline: Support that is free from judgement

_graphic.alt: Image in a circle shape of a girl wearing bright clothing stood in front of a dark wall.

title: Quote
body:
“Have respect for the way they see their own situation. It’s much better for them to understand why something is wrong then to be told by someone else that it is.”

REF: Association of Young People's Health Partnership (AYPH), Be Healthy Project

title: Trust and communication
body:
Trust and communication work both ways. Be friendly, open, approachable and reassure the young person that support and help are available to them. This helps the young person to feel more comfortable.

Children and young people do not want things ‘done to them’. They want professionals to do things with them or for them (e.g. fully involving them in completing or developing their own risk assessment). You can do this using the local CSE risk assessment tool.

title: Support without a disclosure
body: You may not be able to gauge immediate danger without more information. You may find that you need to build more trust with the child or young person.
instruction: Work your way through the slider to consider what actions you can take if you do not get a disclosure but have concerns:
mobileInstruction: Work your way through the slider to consider what actions you can take if you do not get a disclosure but have concerns:

_items.title: Access other services
_items.body: Support the young person to access other services (e.g. such as sexual health), to ensure other needs are being met.

_graphic.alt: Graphic of two hands around a heart shape.

_items.title: Seek advice and share information
_items.body: Seek advice and share or gather information with partner agencies and parents or carers. However, only if safe to do so. Remember that the abuse may be much more serious than the information you have implies.

_graphic.alt: A graphic showing 3 people with a speech bubble.
Image in a circle shape showing a pen and paper and a pair of hands gesturing.

title: Information sharing
body:
Sharing information with other professionals working with a young person may be needed to expose the seriousness of the risk. It is important to always raise any concerns, even if a young person has not made a disclosure, by following your Safeguarding procedures.  

If a child or young person is in immediate danger, you must follow local safeguarding protocols and refer to Social Care and/or the police to ensure that no further harm occurs.

The duty to share information is as important as the duty to protect patient confidentiality if a young person is at risk of harm.

Always ask the young person for consent before sharing confidential information, unless there is a compelling reason for not doing so (e.g. the child is in danger). If you cannot obtain consent to share information, then do so with their knowledge, if possible.

Keep reminding them that the offer of help is always there, even if they reject it. 

Association of Young People's Health Partnership (AYPH), Be Healthy project

title: Quote
body:
“Always think about how this stuff makes young people feel. How would you feel if personal information about you is being shared? If nothing else, think about the consequences for us: how might this affects our lives? All relationships? Or confidence in services and you?”

REF: Association of Young People's Health Partnership (AYPH), Be Healthy project

_graphic.alt: Image in a triangular shape showing a close up of a girl on the phone.

title: Responding to CSE
body:
All professionals working within healthcare settings, no matter what the role, can help support young people affected by CSE by being vigilant in reporting any suspicions in line with local safeguarding protocol.

Local specialist sexual abuse and exploitation services and national organisations (e.g. NSPCC, Barnardos and Brook), are there to help and can be contacted if more information is required.

Each UK nation has its own guidance for professionals about responding to child abuse and protecting children and young people from harm, which includes CSE.

There are also legislative and procedural frameworks for dealing with adult and child perpetrators. A number of regions within the UK are specifically setting up a multidisciplinary approach to dealing with CSE. It is important for professionals to know the local sexual assault/exploitation care pathway.

_graphic.alt: Image in a square shape of a group of people sat around a table having a meeting.

title: A multi-agency response
body:
The Independent Inquiry into Child Sexual Abuse stresses the importance of multi-agency working.

One interview reported;

“during the years she was abused, she regularly attended a sexual health clinic and her GP for numerous morning-after pills and more than one abortion. She believes there should have been communication between the two services, and that she should have been questioned about her frequent visits”.

REF: Independent Inquiry Child Sexual Abuse, The Truth Project

title: Key principles for sharing information
body:
A multi-disciplinary approach to CSE has implications to confidentiality. The key principles of safeguarding also apply (e.g. do not promise confidence that you cannot keep). Information sharing is crucial for successful safeguarding.

The Caldicott review provides seven key principles for sharing information.

REF: HM Government - Advice for practitioners providing safeguarding services (2018)

REF: Department of Health - To share or not to Share (2013)
instruction: Click on the hotspots to find out more:

_graphic.alt: Graphic of 7 different shapes, each with a number from 1 to 7 in them.

mobileInstruction: Work your way through the slider and click on the buttons to explore further:

_items.title: Principle 1
_items.body: Don’t use personal confidential data unless absolutely necessary.

_graphic.alt: Graphic of a green square with the number 1 in the centre.

_items.title: Principle 2
_items.body: Justify the purpose(s): every personal confidential data transfer must be appropriate.

_graphic.alt: Graphic of a turquoise circle with the number 2 in the centre.

_items.title: Principle 3
_items.body: Use the minimum necessary personal confidential data.

_graphic.alt: Graphic of a blue triangle with the number 3 in the centre.

_items.title: Principle 4
_items.body: Access to personal confidential data should be on a strictly need-to-know basis.

_graphic.alt: Graphic of a purple square with the number 4 in the centre.

_items.title: Principle 5
_items.body: Make sure everyone with access to personal confidential data is aware of their responsibilities.

_graphic.alt: Graphic of a yellow tear drop shape with the number 5 in the centre.

_items.title: Principle 6
_items.body: Comply with the law.

_graphic.alt: Graphic of an orange triangle with the number 6 in the centre.

_items.title: Principle 7
_items.body:
The duty to share information is as important as the duty to protect patient confidentiality.

The GDPR and Data Protection Act 2018 place duties on organisations and individuals to process personal information fairly and lawfully; they are not a barrier to sharing information, where the failure to do so would cause the safety or well-being of a child to be compromised.

_graphic.alt: Graphic of a blue circle with the number 7 in the centre.

title: Case Study: How Brook supports young people at risk of CSE
displayTitle: Case Study: How Brook supports young people at risk of CSE
instruction: Work your way through the slider to explore the measures Brook take to support young people at risk of CSE:
mobileInstruction: Work your way through the slider to explore the measures Brook take to support young people at risk of CSE:

_items.title: Here to help
_items.body:
All young people that we work with at Brook receive a warm welcome, and are reassured that we are there to listen, help and support them. We also try to target people from vulnerable groups through posters, leaflets and TV screens in our waiting rooms, to send the message we are here to help.

Brook

_graphic.alt: Image of young Brook worker

_items.title: Reception staff training
_items.body: Our reception staff are trained to assess who is accompanying a young person, or who has dropped them off at a service, to help determine if any coercion or possible exploitation may be taking place.

_graphic.alt: Image of female Brook reception staff

_items.title: Private consultations
_items.body: We ask to see all young people alone for a consultation to allow them a safe space to disclose any abuse or exploitation that they may be experiencing.

_graphic.alt: A young woman in consultation with a Brook staff member

_items.title: Health and risk assessments
_items.body:
When we see a young person in a clinical, education 1-to-1, or counselling consultation, we complete a full health and risk assessment.

We are trained to ask questions in a sensitive way which enables us to explore their:

  • home environment
  • support networks
  • online activity
  • engagement with school

Above all else to identify risk taking behaviour, or risk of serious harm.

_graphic.alt: Image of a Brook staff member talking

_items.title: Confidentiality
_items.body: We always say to a young person that we maintain confidentiality, unless we identify, or they disclose, that they, or someone else is at risk of harm.

_graphic.alt: A young woman talking to a male Brook staff member

_items.title: Policy, support and referrals
_items.body:
Where we identify that a young person is currently at risk of CSE or has experienced exploitation, abuse, or non-consensual sex, we would follow Brook’s Protecting People Policy. This has clear step by step processes to follow.

Expert Safeguarding Leads are also on hand to help and support staff in decision making. This enables them to feel confident and be competent to safeguard young people effectively.

Brook have well established relationships with referral agencies and know which local referral pathways to follow. We refer to Children’s Social Care in the first instance, and to the Police if deemed necessary to protect and support the young person.

_graphic.alt: A young woman reading a flyer

_items.title: Ongoing support
_items.body:
Further to safeguarding the young person, we would then ensure appropriate support was offered to them.

This aims to:

  • build resilience
  • increase their understanding of safe and meaningful relationships, consent, and sexual health
  • equip them with the skills and confidence to negotiate future situations
  • help them make safe and positive choices going forward

_graphic.alt: 3 Brook staff members in discussion

title: Supporting young people affected by CSE
displayTitle: Supporting young people affected by CSE
body:
Sexual exploitation will impact each individual’s psychological and physical health differently. It is important to be able to make the appropriate referrals to address these needs immediately to reduce anxiety and risk to the young person.

Potential symptoms of exploitation that require immediate specialist intervention may include:

  • post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD)
  • repeated STIs
  • repeat requests for emergency contraception
  • pregnancy
  • psychological trauma
  • self-harming
  • suicidal ideation and/or suicide attempts
  • depression
  • substance misuse

REF: Health Working Group Report on Child Sexual Exploitation
instruction: Click on the tab to find out more:

_items.title: Where should you refer?
_items.body:
You must have a robust awareness of local statutory and non-statutory services that can respond to the potential needs of individuals who have experienced CSE.

This information should be embedded within your local child protection or safeguarding policy and you must take responsibility for being familiar with these and know which local service is the most affective for each individual and their specific need.

Possible referral pathways include:

  • Child and Adolescent Mental Health Services (CAMHS)
  • School nurse teams
  • Sexual Assault Referral Centres (SARC)
  • Children’s Social Care
  • Third Sector early help
  • Counselling
  • Sexual health services
  • Brook
  • Youth groups
  • Youth services
  • GPs

title: Survivors Manchester: PTSD as a result of CSE
displayTitle: Survivors Manchester: PTSD as a result of CSE
body:
PTSD (post traumatic stress disorder) is thought to be an extremely common but under-diagnosed disorder in survivors of sexual abuse.

Survivors Manchester
instruction: Work your way through the slider to read Damon’s story:
mobileInstruction: Work your way through the slider to read Damon’s story:

_items.title: Damon’s story
_items.body:
Damon was 11 when Luke (58) started touching him, telling him:

“I’m teaching you how to be a man”

Over the next four years, Damon was sexually abused and raped on a number of occasions.

The majority of the time, the sexual abuse happened in the communal public toilets and Damon’s memory absorbed the smells, sights and sounds of this setting.

_graphic.alt: Image of a boy with a tight afro, wearing a bright red jacket looking down a street.

_items.title: Experiences of PTSD
_items.body:
For the next 18 years Damon found it hard to use public toilets and would sometimes wretch when he was in the proximity of someone using bleach.

Other times, Damon will be walking down the road and suddenly would feel like his whole body was back at the moment of being raped.

_graphic.alt: Image of a bathroom covered in posters and graffiti.

_items.title: Getting help and support
_items.body:
PTSD was debilitating for him but once he found the right support, he was able to better integrate with everyday life.

Therapeutic sessions enabled him and his therapist to identify the likelihood of the severity of his PTSD, whilst undergoing treatment helped him process the traumatic experiences and conclude that these feelings and memories were in the past.

_graphic.alt: Image of a man sat with a family having dinner.
Image of a man sat in a cafe on his laptop.

title: Support for professionals
body:
It can be very challenging working with children and young people who have been sexually exploited. It is important that you have the option of accessing your own emotional support.

Brook recommends using your own networks, colleagues and supervisors. Supervision is especially valuable as it gives you the opportunity to discuss concerns and anxieties and to get support when needed.
instruction: Click on the tab to find out more:

_items.title: Other advice and support
_items.body:
The following organisations can also provide advice and support:

British Medical Association

General Medical Council

NHS Confederation

British Association of Counsellors and Psychotherapy

UK Council for Psychotherapy

National Association for People Abused in Childhood

title: Summary
body:
Safeguarding is everyone’s responsibility, and everyone has a responsibility to support children and young people and to report any suspicions that they may have about a child or young person's welfare to ensure that they are protected from harm.

If you have any concerns, remember to follow your organisation’s safeguarding policy and procedure.

title: Quote
body:
“If you can’t rule it out,
rule it in.”

REF: Barnardo's

title: Question 1
body: Which of the statements listed below do you think correctly summarise what you have discovered so far?
instruction: Select all that apply:

_items.text: There’s a legal definition of child sexual exploitation (CSE)
CSE is not limited to any specific section of society
Most CSE is disclosed by those affected by it
There are several models that describes CSE

_feedback.title: Feedback:
_feedback.correct:
That's right

There are laws to protect all children and young people from CSE.

CSE can take many forms, all of which involve one person having power over another person which they use to sexually exploit them.

CSE is not limited to a narrow section of society and unfortunately, most of the people experiencing CSE do not report it. It’s important to remember that boys and young men can also experience CSE.

title: Question 2
body:
It is important to dispel myths related to CSE because they result in children and young people not receiving the help they need.

Which of the following statements do you think are false?
instruction: Select all that apply:

_items.text: It mainly happens to white children and young people
It happens only to children and young people in care and those from disadvantaged families
Abusers are always male and they target girls
It can often be committed by young people onto other young people

_feedback.title: Feedback:
_feedback.correct:
That's right

CSE happens to boys and young men as well as girls and young women. It can be perpetrated by adult men and women, and other children and young people. Most of those affected by CSE live at home.

The circumstances in which young people agree to sex are often so socially coercive that regardless of the young person’s age, the consent is not real and the young person is being abused and exploited.

title: Question 3
body:
There are many reasons why children and young people delay or never disclose abuse (e.g. pressure and threats from abusers, fear of isolation or rejection, or not recognising it as abuse).

We have a duty to pick up on the signs and indicators and support young people to disclose when ready.

Which of the following do you think are some other reasons given for not disclosing?
instruction: Select all that apply:

_items.text: They think there's no one to talk to who will listen, take them seriously or can be trusted
Boys and young men can often feel looked upon as a perpetrator especially if they are already involved in the youth justice system
They are embarrassed, or ashamed, or fearful of the consequences
Nothing will change, or it may become worse if they disclose the abuse
Disclosure is not the best way the deal with abuse

_feedback.title: Feedback:
_feedback.correct:
That's right

Children and young people often report feeling:

  • embarrassed
  • reluctant to burden others
  • fearful of getting themselves or someone else in trouble
  • fearful of a loss of control over the information that is shared
  • fearful of how that information is acted upon by adults

They are least likely to tell someone in authority but are most likely to disclose to someone they think will believe them (e.g. a parent or friend). Research indicates that boys and young men find it especially difficult to disclose, are reluctant to be identified as a ‘victim’ and therefore can avoid services and support.

title: Question 4
body: Which of the following statements do you think are true?
instruction: Select all that apply:

_items.text: Dealing with CSE requires a coordinated approach
CSE is a safeguarding issue
Young people find opportunities to disclose abuse they have experienced
I need to comply with the law and use my skills to ensure that in doing so the young person nevertheless feels respected

_feedback.title: Feedback:
_feedback.correct:
That's right

So far over 4,000 people have shared their experience of CSA via the Independent Inquiry Child Sexual Abuse, ‘The Truth Project’ highlights the missed opportunities to identify and deal effectively with CSE in the past.

However, developments in safeguarding legislation and arrangements nationally now provide the opportunity to develop a coordinated approach that is child-centred but also protects the child further from harm. Concerns should be raised, and children and young people supported to disclose abuse free from guilt, shame and judgement. Healthcare workers may find opportunities to broach the subject tactfully with individuals.

title: What is CSE?
body:
The majority of children and young people in the UK grow up to have happy and healthy sexual development, free from harm. However, some do not.

CSE is a form of sexual abuse that happens in all communities and much of it remains hidden and unreported. It can happen to young people regardless of gender and be perpetrated by men, women, children and peers.

title: Module 2: Spotting the signs and barriers to disclosure
body:
There is no single list of warning signs that you can use to assess whether the person sitting in front of you is being abused.

However, there may be physical, psychological or behavioural signs that prompt you to ask further questions.

REF: Children's Commissioner - 'If only someone had listened'

title: Module 3: Working with young people and safeguarding
body:
Safeguarding is everyone’s responsibility. Everyone has a responsibility to support children and young people and to report any suspicions that they may have about their welfare to ensure that they are protected from harm.

If you have any concerns, you must follow your organisation’s safeguarding policy and procedure.

REF: HM Government, 2018 - Working Together to Safeguard Children

REF: Children and Social Work Act, 2017

REF: Home Office Multi-Agency Working and Information Sharing Project, June 2013

_graphic.alt: An image of a girl with her arms around her mother.

title: Useful resources
body: Useful resources

_graphic.alt: Graphic of a pie chart indicating '7.5% of adults experience sexual abuse before the age of 16 years'.

title: A note on age
body:
A person under the age of 18 years is regarded as a child under UK law.

Although the age of consent to sexual activity is 16 years, CSE includes young people up to the age of 18 because of the nature of the abuse.

It is important to keep in mind that 16 and 17 year olds may also experience sexual exploitation. No child consents to their own abuse. Adults always have power over young children and young people.

REF: Crime Survey for England and Wales (CSEW) 2020

title: How can CSE occur?
body: Child sexual exploitation can happen in person or online.
instruction: Work your way through the buttons to explore some examples of how child sexual exploitation can occur:

_items.title: Peer-on-peer CSE
_items.body:
Peer-on-peer CSE is when ‘children are sexually exploited by peers who are known to them at school, in the neighbourhood or through mutual friends’. It is estimated that peer-on-peer offending accounts for a quarter of CSE offences across the UK, although this can be much higher in areas such as London. According to a report produced by The Mayor's Office for Policing and Crime (MOPAC) and NHS England: ‘In peer-on-peer abuse, there can be substantial cross overs between victim and offender with victims facilitating or coercing others into inappropriate sexual behaviours’.

Boys and young men can be the victims and perpetrators of CSE and can be especially vulnerable to CSE by older males. In the context of gangs, they can be forced, pressurised or bullied to take part in sexual activities or abuse of others in return for their own protection. Social media and messaging platforms are often linked to peer-to-peer sexual exploitation. 

Video: My New Friend

REF: PACE - Child sexual exploitation grooming and models

REF: MOPAC & NHS England - Sexual violence against children and young people (2016)

REF: Centre of Expertise on Child Sexual Abuse - Scoping report (2018)

_graphic.alt: Image of a girl looking down.

_items.title: Gang activity and county lines
_items.body:
Young people with various and intertwined vulnerabilities such as mental health, special educational needs or issues at home (e.g. abuse or neglect) are at the greatest risk of being groomed and recruited into gangs involved in criminal activity. Part of a gangs’ business model is often to exploit recruits to sell or carry drugs outside of the local authority area, using mobile phones to supply drugs. This is referred to as ‘County Lines’. 

The Children’s Society state that: ‘These criminals groom children into trafficking their drugs for them with promises of money, friendship and status. Once they've been drawn in, these children are controlled using threats, violence and sexual abuse, leaving them traumatised and living in fear’.

REF: Children's Commissioners Report - Keeping kids safe

REF: The Children's Society (2020) - What is County Lines?

_graphic.alt: Image of a hooded person walking away.

_items.title: Online abuse
_items.body:
Social networking sites and messaging apps are increasingly used by abusers to groom, blackmail, threaten and coerce. Perpetrators of CSE will often manipulate or force children and young people into sending or viewing indecent images and/or filming themselves. This can be used as blackmail to elicit more images or sexual acts and can be shared with other abusers.

The age of those accessing online platforms is getting younger, which means younger children are increasingly at risk of CSE. Perpetrators will also regularly provide mobiles as gifts, which are then used to track and control the child.

Young people who identify as LGBTQ+ may seek support around their sexuality online and via dating apps which can make them vulnerable to CSE.

REF: CEOP - What is online child sexual abuse and exploitation?

REF: University of Bedfordshire (2011) - What's going on to safeguard children and young people from sexual exploitation?

REF: Fearless - What is Child Sexual Exploitation?

REF: Barnardo's - ‘It’s not on the radar’ (2015)

_graphic.alt: Image of a person on an iPad.
